topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Dr. Fei-Fei Li’s impact on modern AI (ImageNet, Stanford HAI, Google Cloud) and frames the episode’s focus: AI history, human impact, and world models, including the launch of Marble.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ads for Figma Make and Justworks.

topics.title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
topics.summary: Fei-Fei explains her non-utopian optimism: AI’s impact is real but shaped by human choices, and society must act responsibly because AI affects individuals, communities, and future generations.

topics.title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
topics.summary: Fei-Fei gives a concise history of AI from the 1950s Dartmouth workshop through expert systems and early neural nets to the rise of statistical machine learning in the 1990s/2000s.

topics.title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
topics.summary: She describes choosing visual intelligence and object recognition as a “north star,” realizing models lacked training data, and building ImageNet (15M images, 22k concepts) to unlock learning at scale.

topics.title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
topics.summary: Fei-Fei recounts the 2012 ImageNet breakthrough (Hinton’s team, two GPUs) and the enduring trio behind modern AI—big data, neural networks, and GPU compute—connecting it to today’s LLMs.

topics.title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
topics.summary: They discuss how companies avoided the term AI around 2015–2016, with 2017 marking a shift toward branding as “AI companies,” contrasting sharply with today’s AI-everywhere landscape.

topics.title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
topics.summary: Fei-Fei critiques AGI as loosely defined and more marketing than science, emphasizing that current AI still fails at basic perception/reasoning tasks and lacks creativity, abstraction, and emotional intelligence.

topics.title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
topics.summary: Fei-Fei explains world models as systems that generate, let users navigate, interact with, and reason about 3D worlds; she argues spatial intelligence is essential beyond language for embodied tasks and real-world understanding.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ad for Sinch and RCS messaging.

topics.title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
topics.summary: Fei-Fei discusses Sutton’s “bitter lesson” (scale wins) and why robotics complicates it: data/action alignment is harder than language, real-world embodiment adds hardware and safety constraints, and progress may resemble long self-driving timelines.

topics.title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
topics.summary: Fei-Fei reflects that building AI increases her respect for humans: the brain runs on ~20 watts yet supports remarkable perception and action.

topics.title: Marble launch: first large world model product
topics.summary: Fei-Fei introduces Marble from World Labs: a “prompt-to-worlds” app built on a frontier model that generates navigable 3D environments; they discuss the deliberate “dot” visualization and early product philosophy.

topics.title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
topics.summary: Fei-Fei shares early adoption: virtual production (claimed ~40x faster), game/VR world building, robotics simulation data generation, and unexpected research uses like psychology experiments and exposure therapy scenarios.
